text: Noon light slips through breaks in the clouds, falling across the tavern sign as dust spins lazily in the beam. The hearth still burns, the air rich with the smell of bread and stew.
I’ve just finished mopping the floor. The bandage at the corner of my mouth still pulls painfully when the doorbell gives a soft chime.
A girl with chestnut hair tied in a short braid steps in, carrying a basket filled with medicine bottles of all colors, like dewdrops sealed in sunlight.
“Sir… excuse me! Does a woman named Alicia happen to be staying here?”
“…She is.” I touch my bandage. “Why?”
Her gaze drops instantly to the bruise on my face. She stiffens visibly.
“You’re hurt?! W-was there trouble?”
“A drunk. He’s gone.”
“Again…” She bites down on the word lightly, then realizes she’s slipped and quickly corrects herself. “I mean… why are people always like that!”
She sets the medicine basket on the counter, quick but careful, as if afraid of hurting me further.
“My name’s Lucia. I’m her apprentice. She didn’t look well this morning before she left… I followed her all the way here.”
“She’s upstairs.”
Before the words fully leave my mouth, a faint set of footsteps sounds outside again—slow and steady, as if arrival itself were a burden.
Alicia walks in. Frost still clings to her silver cloak, a trace of mud marking the edge of her armor. Her eyes are distant—so distant it’s as if she’s sealed all emotion inside.
“Master!”
Lucia nearly rushes to her, but stops abruptly two steps away, as though afraid that touching her too hard might cause her to shatter.
“Don’t shout.”
“I can hear you.”
She pulls her cloak tighter around her shoulders. Her gaze passes over the bruise on my face without expression—as though she has seen this same scene too many times before.
“You looked awful this morning! I told you I’d come with you, but you wouldn’t let me… did you do it again—”
“Lucia.” She cuts her off, her voice quiet but sharp, like a dull blade slicing the sentence in two. “Not here.”
Lucia swallows the rest of her words. Her eyes redden almost instantly.
“…Then at least sit down. Your hands are shaking.”
“I’m fine.”
“You always say that!”
Her voice is full of worry, edged with a kind of anger only someone close would dare show.
“Lucia… would you like something hot? I’ve got some stew.”
“Yes! Thank you!”
She immediately turns back to her medicine basket, as if finally grasping something she can actually do.
“Sir, that wound needs disinfecting. I have herbal salve here… and something for the pain.”
“…You don’t have to go to the trouble.”
“It’s no trouble! You got hurt because of her, didn’t you?”
The moment she says it, she looks at Alicia, as if afraid she’s struck something sensitive.
“Don’t pin it on me.”
“If he got hit, that’s his bad luck.”
She says it coldly, as if cutting all responsibility away. But her fingers tighten slightly inside her sleeve—a tiny motion, as if suppressing something.
“Master… please don’t.”
“This is how I am.”
She walks to the notice board behind the counter, glancing at the room keys as if confirming something she already knew.
“Two rooms.”
“…You’re staying together?”
“No.”
“She gets one. I get one.”
Lucia freezes, clearly wanting to protest, but forces herself not to. She hugs her medicine basket like a cushion, ready to catch her if she collapses.
“Then I’ll take the room next to yours! So if you feel unwell in the night, I’ll hear you.”
“Suit yourself.”
Her answer is cold, but she doesn’t refuse. As if even refusal would take too much effort.
“Sir, let me treat that wound first. Don’t move.”
She applies the salve to the split at the corner of my mouth with the care one might use on porcelain.
“…Don’t use that one.”
“Why?”
“It’ll make the wound heal too quickly.”
She says it like common knowledge. Lucia visibly startles, panic flickering in her eyes—as if she’s heard an experience that shouldn’t exist.
“…Then I’ll switch to the regular one.”
Alicia says nothing more. She drapes her cloak over the chair back and sits. In that single motion, she seems to finally exhale—like someone who might fall asleep and never wake.
The brass die rests quietly on the counter. Lucia is busy tending to me, while Alicia seems utterly detached from the warmth around her.
Her coldness isn’t arrogance. It’s more like she’s locked herself inside a shell—because if she opens it, she’ll fall apart.

options.text: Option A: Ask Alicia directly in front of Lucia, “What’s wrong with you today?” 【Charisma Check (DC 6)】
Option B: Wait and find a chance to ask her privately 【No Check (DC 0)】
